definitions: discourage or prevent someone from doing something by making them afraid or doubtful
examples: The high fence deters intruders from entering the property
Security cameras deter shoplifters from stealing merchandise in stores

definitions: become gradually worse in quality, condition, or value over time
examples: The abandoned building started to deteriorate after years of neglect
His health began to deteriorate when he stopped taking medication

definitions: remove a monarch from their throne or anyone from a position of authority
examples: The revolution aimed to dethrone the corrupt king from power
The new champion will dethrone the current titleholder next month

definitions: explode or cause something to explode with sudden violent release of energy
examples: The bomb squad will detonate the suspicious package in a safe area
Lightning can detonate explosive gases in underground mines during storms

definitions: take a longer alternative route to avoid something or reach a destination
examples: We had to detour around the flooded road to reach town
The hikers decided to detour through the valley for better views

definitions: remove toxic substances from the body through medical treatment or special diet
examples: She went to detox from alcohol at a rehabilitation center
Many people detox with juice cleanses after the holiday season

definitions: take away from the value, quality, or importance of something
examples: The loud music detracts from the restaurant's romantic atmosphere completely
Poor grammar will detract from your essay's overall effectiveness significantly

definitions: reduce or lower the value, worth, or importance of something
examples: The government decided to devalue the currency to boost exports
Don't devalue your achievements by comparing yourself to others constantly

definitions: destroy something completely or cause severe emotional pain and shock to someone
examples: The hurricane will devastate coastal communities if it makes landfall
The news of her friend's death devastated her for many months

definitions: depart or turn away from an established course, path, or standard
examples: The plane had to deviate from its flight path due to storms
Don't deviate from the recipe if you want perfect results today

definitions: plan, invent, or create something through careful thought and imagination
examples: The engineers will devise a solution to fix the bridge problem
She managed to devise a clever escape plan from the locked room

definitions: transfer power or responsibility to a lower level of government or organization
gradually deteriorate or degenerate into a worse condition or state
examples: The federal government will devolve certain powers to state authorities
Parliament voted to devolve more control to local councils this year
The peaceful protest began to devolve into violent confrontations with police
Their friendly debate started to devolve into personal attacks and insults

definitions: eat food quickly and hungrily in large amounts
read, watch, or take in something eagerly and rapidly
examples: The hungry teenagers devour everything in the refrigerator after school
Lions devour their prey within minutes of making a successful kill
She would devour mystery novels during her summer vacation every year
Film students devour classic movies to learn about cinematography techniques

definitions: draw or create a simplified drawing that shows how something works or is arranged
examples: The teacher will diagram the sentence structure on the whiteboard today
Engineers diagram complex systems before building the actual machines

definitions: enter or select a telephone number to make a phone call
turn or adjust a control knob or wheel to a specific setting
examples: Please dial the emergency number if you need immediate medical help
She had to dial the wrong number three times before reaching him
Dial the thermostat down to save energy during the summer months
The radio host asked listeners to dial up the volume

definitions: negotiate or bargain persistently over the terms of a transaction, especially price
examples: Tourists often dicker with vendors at the local market for souvenirs
The two companies continue to dicker over the merger agreement details

definitions: speak words aloud for someone else to write down or for recording
control or decisively affect something or give orders with total authority
examples: The doctor will dictate patient notes into the voice recorder later
She asked her assistant to dictate the letter while she typed
Weather conditions dictate when the mountain climbing season begins each year
Parents shouldn't dictate every aspect of their children's lives completely

definitions: waste time by being indecisive or doing trivial activities
cheat or swindle someone out of something, especially money
examples: Stop diddling around and finish your homework before dinner tonight
He would diddle with his phone instead of paying attention in class
The con artist tried to diddle elderly people out of their savings
Don't let that salesman diddle you with hidden fees and charges

definitions: recognize or identify the differences between two or more things clearly
make or become different in the process of growth or development
examples: Color-blind people cannot differentiate between certain shades of red and green
The test helps differentiate genuine diamonds from synthetic ones quickly
Stem cells differentiate into specialized cells during embryonic development stages
The company needs to differentiate its products from competitor offerings

definitions: spread over a wide area or between many people gradually
make something less concentrated, intense, or strong by spreading it out
examples: Light will diffuse through the frosted glass creating soft illumination
The pleasant aroma began to diffuse throughout the entire house
Adding water will diffuse the paint making it more transparent
The mediator tried to diffuse the tension between arguing parties

definitions: break down food in the stomach and intestines for body absorption
think about information carefully to understand it fully and completely
examples: Your stomach needs several hours to digest a heavy meal properly
Some people cannot digest dairy products due to lactose intolerance
Students need time to digest complex mathematical concepts before solving problems
I need to digest this report before making any important decisions

definitions: convert information, images, or sound into digital form for computer processing
examples: The library plans to digitize its entire collection of historical documents
Many companies digitize paper records to save storage space and money

definitions: build an embankment or wall to prevent flooding from water
examples: The villagers worked together to dike the river before flood season
Engineers will dike the low-lying areas to protect them from storms

definitions: make a liquid thinner or weaker by adding water or another solvent
make something weaker in force, effect, or value by modification
examples: Dilute the concentrated juice with three parts water before drinking
The nurse will dilute the medicine to make it safe for children
Adding too many features will dilute the product's core value proposition
Don't dilute your message by trying to appeal to everyone equally

definitions: make or become less bright by reducing the amount of light
make or become less clear, distinct, or likely to happen
examples: Please dim the lights before the movie starts in the theater
The sunset began to dim as clouds moved across the sky
His memories of childhood began to dim as years passed by
Don't let temporary setbacks dim your hopes for future success

definitions: produce or form small natural hollows in a surface, especially in cheeks when smiling
examples: Her cheeks dimple whenever she smiles at something funny or sweet
The golf ball will dimple when hit with extreme force

definitions: make a loud, unpleasant, and prolonged noise that continues without stopping
examples: The construction workers din from morning until evening every weekday
Traffic continues to din outside our apartment windows all night long

definitions: eat dinner or another formal meal, typically in a restaurant or as a guest
examples: We plan to dine at the new French restaurant downtown tonight
The ambassador will dine with the president at the state dinner

definitions: make a short ringing sound like that of a bell
make a small dent or damage in a surface
examples: The elevator will ding when it reaches your floor number
The timer began to ding indicating the cookies were ready
Be careful not to ding the car door on the concrete pillar
Someone managed to ding my bicycle while it was parked outside

definitions: put or lower something briefly into liquid and then take it out
go down temporarily to a lower level or amount before rising again
examples: Dip the brush in paint before applying it to the canvas
She likes to dip her cookies in milk before eating them
Stock prices tend to dip before major holiday weekends each year
The temperature will dip below freezing tonight according to forecasts

definitions: make a device, system, or feature unable to function or operate properly
cause someone to have a physical or mental condition that limits their abilities
examples: The technician will disable the alarm system during maintenance work today
You can disable notifications in your phone's settings menu easily
The accident could disable him from walking for several months
A stroke can disable a person's ability to speak clearly

definitions: put someone or something in an unfavorable or less advantageous position compared to others
examples: The new regulations disadvantage small businesses trying to compete with corporations
Poor internet access will disadvantage rural students during online learning periods

definitions: refuse to allow, accept, or recognize something as valid or acceptable
examples: The referee will disallow the goal due to an offside violation
The judge decided to disallow the evidence presented by the defense

definitions: fail to meet the expectations or hopes of someone, causing sadness or displeasure
examples: I hate to disappoint you but the concert has been cancelled
Parents should try not to disappoint their children with broken promises

definitions: have or express an unfavorable opinion about something or someone's actions
examples: Her parents disapprove of her decision to quit medical school
The committee will likely disapprove the proposal due to budget constraints

definitions: take weapons away from a person, group, or country
make someone less hostile or suspicious through charm or friendliness
examples: Police officers must disarm suspects before taking them into custody
The treaty requires both nations to disarm their nuclear weapons
Her warm smile could disarm even the angriest customer quickly
He used humor to disarm his critics during the debate

definitions: throw something into a state of disorder, confusion, or untidiness
examples: The sudden storm will disarray all our outdoor party preparations completely
Moving furniture around managed to disarray the entire living room

definitions: disconnect or separate oneself from a person, group, or organization
examples: The company decided to disassociate from its controversial business partner
She had to disassociate herself from her troubled past completely

definitions: deny any responsibility for, knowledge of, or connection with something
examples: The politician tried to disavow his earlier controversial statements publicly
The company will disavow any warranty claims after the expiration date

definitions: cause an organized group to break up and stop functioning as a unit
examples: The committee will disband after completing its investigation next month
The band decided to disband due to creative differences between members

definitions: get rid of something as no longer useful, needed, or wanted
examples: Please discard any expired medications at the pharmacy disposal bin
Don't discard these receipts until after you file your taxes

definitions: perceive, recognize, or distinguish something that is not immediately obvious or clear
examples: It's difficult to discern the truth when everyone tells different stories
Art experts can discern fake paintings from authentic masterpieces easily

definitions: officially release someone from a duty, hospital, prison, or employment
release or allow a substance to flow out from where it was confined
examples: The hospital will discharge the patient after reviewing test results tomorrow
The army will discharge soldiers who complete their service contracts
Factories must not discharge toxic waste into rivers or lakes
The clouds began to discharge heavy rain across the valley

definitions: change to a different color in a way that looks unattractive or damaged
examples: Sunlight will discolor the fabric if you leave it exposed too long
Smoking can discolor your teeth over time making them yellow

definitions: break the connection between two things physically, electronically, or emotionally
examples: The technician will disconnect the cable before replacing the modem
Try to disconnect from work emails during your vacation time

definitions: stop doing, using, producing, or providing something that was previously regular
examples: The manufacturer will discontinue this product line next year permanently
The doctor advised her to discontinue the medication causing side effects

definitions: harm the good reputation or credibility of a person, idea, or organization
examples: False accusations can discredit an honest person's reputation unfairly
The scandal will discredit the politician's campaign for reelection completely

definitions: treat people unfairly based on prejudice about race, age, gender, or other characteristics
recognize and understand the difference between things or people
examples: It's illegal to discriminate against employees based on their religious beliefs
Some landlords discriminate against tenants with children or pets unfairly
Wine experts can discriminate between subtle flavors in different vintages
Color-blind individuals cannot discriminate between certain shades effectively

definitions: consider something or someone as unworthy of respect and show contempt
examples: She would disdain any offer of help from her former friends
Intellectuals sometimes disdain popular culture as inferior entertainment
